The text mentions several series of paintings by Claude Monet, including The Station of Saint-Lazare, Haystacks, The Poplars, The Cathedral of Rouen, The Parliament of London, San Giorgio Maggiore, and Water Lilies. While each series focuses on a different subject, they all share Monet's impressionist style and his interest in depicting the changing effects of light and atmosphere on his subjects. For example, in the Haystacks series, Monet painted the same haystacks at different times of the day and year to capture the varying light and weather conditions. Similarly, in the Cathedral of Rouen series, Monet painted the same cathedral repeatedly to explore the way the changing light affected its appearance. Overall, Monet's series paintings are a testament to his commitment to observing and capturing the natural world in all its complexity and variability.
